sa13.74:1.2: One time, the Buddha was staying at Anāthapiṇḍada Park in Jeta Grove in Śrāvastī.
sa13.74:2.1: It was then that the Bhagavān addressed the monks,
sa13.74:2.3: Listen closely and well consider it.
sa13.74:2.4: I will explain this for you.
sa13.74:3.2: This refers to wrong view … wrong concentration.
sa13.74:3.4: This refers to right view … right concentration.
sa13.74:4.2: That refers to teaching that there’s generosity, there’s the teaching, there are observances, there’s good conduct and bad conduct, and there are the results of good and bad conduct.
sa13.74:4.3: There’s this world, and there’s the other world.
sa13.74:4.4: There’s father and mother and the birth of sentient beings.
sa13.74:4.5: There are arhats who well arrive, are well headed, and know and realize for themselves the perfect abode, whether it’s in this or the other world:
sa13.74:4.6: ‘My births have ended, the religious practice has been established, the task has been accomplished, and I know I won’t be subject to a later existence.’
sa13.74:5.2: It’s the intent of renunciation, intent without anger, and intent that’s not harmful.
sa13.74:6.2: It’s being free of false speech, free of duplicity, free of harsh words, and free of fancy speech.
sa13.74:7.2: It’s being free of killing, stealing, and sexual misconduct.
sa13.74:8.2: It’s pursuing clothing, food and drink, bedding, and medicines in ways according to the Dharma and not contrary to the Dharma.
sa13.74:9.2: It’s desire, effort, method, separation, striving, and the capability to work constantly and not retreat.
sa13.74:10.2: It’s mindfully following and remembering that’s not false or vacant.
sa13.74:11.2: It’s abiding with mind unconfused, resolute, collected, tranquil, concentrated, and single-minded.”
sa13.74:12.1: After the Buddha taught this sutra, the monks who heard what he taught rejoiced and handed it down.
